metadata.case_name: Sadiq Ali and another v. Election Commission of India and others
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 70 of 1971; Civil Appeals Nos. 2122 to 2124 of 1970

facts.text: Shri S. Nijalingappa was elected President of the Congress with effect from 1st January, 1968 for a period of two years.
Dr. Zakir Hussain, President of India, died in 1969 leading to split in Congress over choice of nominee for President of India.
One group elected Shri C. Subramaniam as President, later Shri Jagjivan Ram (Congress J). Shri Nijalingappa continued as President of Congress O.
On 21st December, 1969, Shri Subramaniam wrote to Chief Election Commissioner claiming change in office-bearers of Congress (Congress J list).
On 3rd January, 1970, communication on behalf of Congress J stated Shri Jagjivan Ram elected President on December 25, 1969 at Bombay plenary.
On 8th January, 1970, Commission sent copy of Subramaniam's letter to Congress O Secretary for comments.
On 14th January, 1970, Shri Sadiq Ali (Congress O) replied denying Subramaniam as President, stating Nijalingappa is President, members expelled, no jurisdiction.
On 15th January, 1970, Commission notified both groups of dispute under para 15 Symbols Order and opportunity to be heard.

On 22nd January 1970, Congress J filed statement: term extension invalid, requisition by 400+ AICC members rejected mala fide, requisitioned AICC meeting 22-23 Nov 1969 attended by 435/707, elected Subramaniam then Jagjivan Ram, Bombay plenary ratified.
Congress J had majority MPs/MLAs, legislature parties support, recognised in Parliament.

On 16th February, 1970, Congress O counter-statement: no jurisdiction, Congress Parliamentary Board chose Sanjiva Reddy, Indira Gandhi etc. defied, removals valid, requisition invalid, attendees personal capacity, defectors.
On 7th March, 1970, Commission framed 4 points: jurisdiction, satisfaction of rival groups, nature of symbol, which group is Congress.
Commission held jurisdiction exists due to total cleavage, satisfied of rival groups, symbol not property, Congress J is Congress by majority test in legislatures and organisation.
Madras High Court on 15th June 1970 upheld in W.As. Nos. 327, 345/1970 and W.P. No. 513/1970.

legal_issues.text: Has the Election Commission jurisdiction under paragraph 15 of the Symbols Order to decide which rival section of Congress is the real Congress?
Was the Commission satisfied there are rival sections each claiming to be Congress?
Nature of election symbol under Symbols Order - is it property?
Which rival section is the Indian National Congress for Symbols Order purposes?
Vires of paragraph 15 of Symbols Order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Commission has no jurisdiction; dispute to be decided by Working Committee or President (Nijalingappa); members of Congress J expelled.
Follow Congress Constitution provisions; term extension valid; requisition invalid; Working Committee majority with Congress O (11 vs 10).
Paragraph 13 Symbols Order governs; para 15 ultra vires.
Supporters of Congress J are defectors; primary members matter, not legislature majority.

respondent_arguments.text: Term extension invalid (no ratification); Nijalingappa's actions mala fide; requisitioned AICC meeting valid, majority support; legislature and organisation majority.
Commission has jurisdiction under para 15; majority test relevant.

court_reasoning.text: Commission has jurisdiction under para 15 due to rival claims; total cleavage justifies inquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conflict creates jurisdiction to decide genuine claims.

court_reasoning.text: Satisfied of rival groups from communications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Information in possession shows two groups claiming to be Congress.

court_reasoning.text: Symbol not property; for voter identification, acquires value but indivisible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal right for elections, not divisible.

court_reasoning.text: Congress J has substantial majority in Parliament, legislatures, AICC, delegates; majority test relevant in democracy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Numerical strength germane; reflects primary members.

court_reasoning.text: Para 15 valid; subserves Symbols Order; Commission has plenary powers under Art 324, Rules 5,10.

holdings.text: Election Commission has jurisdiction under para 15 Symbols Order to decide which rival group is the recognised political party for symbol purposes.
Congress (J) is the Indian National Congress entitled to symbol 'Two Bullocks with Yoke On' based on majority support.
Paragraph 15 of Symbols Order is intra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Assembly of Free Church of Scotland v. Lord Overtoun
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishable as concerns property and change of religious tenets, not political party split over symbols.

precedents_cited.case_name: Samyukta Socialist Party v. Election Commission of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerns merger and separation of parties, different from rival groups claiming to be same party.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests superintendence of elections in Commission; para 15 subserves this.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires Commission to specify symbols and issue directions to Returning Officers.

statutes_cited.name: Election Symbols (Reservation and Allotment) Order, 1968
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs recognition, symbols, disputes between rival groups; para 15 for resolving which group is the party.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upheld Election Commission's decision that Congress (J) under Shri Jagjivan Ram is the Indian National Congress entitled to the reserved symbol 'Two Bullocks with Yoke On' for elections, confirmed jurisdiction and validity of para 15 Symbols Order, and Madras High Court judgment.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; symbol allotted to Congress J candidates.

key_quotes.text: The test of majority and numerical strength, in our opinion, was not only germane and relevant but a very valuable test.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for upholding Commission's decision.

key_quotes.text: If there are facts... which show a total and entire cleavage... the very existence of such a conflict is enough to create jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The symbol cannot be split. It is only one of the rival sections or groups... which would be entitled to the use of the symbol.
key_quotes.speaker: court
